data.title: Quickselect (find Nth ordered statistic in mostly linear time)
data.body:
This adds the Select class to utils, which is modeled after the Sort class, allowing Array to call into it to get the nth item in an array based on a Comparator.  It currently uses Quickselect, but could be configured to use other algorithms without breaking the API.

Array now has methods like Array.selectRanked that act much like Array.sort(), except for selection instead of sorting.

See also the commit inside the PR with tests if you want to verify correctness. I passed all the tests when I ran and I also dropped the new gdx.jar into my game where I used it to find the nearest enemy units (no bugs). In fact I mostly made this because finding new enemy targets based on distance was taking up a lot of cpu time in my game.

Eager for criticisms and suggestions.

UPDATE:
It makes a smart choice between a naive single-pass algorithm or quickselect based on the value of k. For k = min or k = max, single-pass is faster and it uses that.  Otherwise, it uses quickselect.

data.title: added setSpriteBatchBeginEnd to BatchTiledMapRenderer to make the sprite...
data.body: ...Batch begin/end calls inside the render method optional. That way BatchTiledMapRenderer  can easily be used with a shared SpriteBatch and no end()/begin() calls are required around the render call. It can also avoid a flush and a texture switch if the map is on the same texture as the following sprites.

data.title: Please support OpenGL 1.4 (i.e. older macbooks) on Desktop Backend
data.body:
Hi, I have an older (2006) macbook and am developing games with libGDX.

Today, I hit a wall when making OpenGL 1.1 calls such as `Gdx.g11.glTexParameteri`. I got a `NullPointerException`, the cause of which can be traced back to the `initiateGLInstances` method of the `LwjglGraphics` class. Because my OpenGL minor version is one less than 5 (i.e., 4), `LwjglGraphics` never instantiates gl11, and any calls to it result in a `NullPointerException`.

Yes, I know I need to upgrade my computer soon, when I can afford it. But the thing is, there is nothing I can see that is preventing these OpenGL 1.1 calls such as `glTexParameteri` from working on the desktop, which uses LWJGL as it's backend. In fact, I know it works because I've made these calls through LWJGL directly on the same computer with no problem.

So please tell me why LWJGL allows me to make OpenGL 1.1 calls on my macbook, but libGDX won't, when it's using LWJGL as it's desktop backend? It makes no sense.

I realize there is probably some 1.5 calls used somewhere to be able to fully support ES 1.x emulation. But it doesn't seem right to nullify the entire GL11 interface because of it. Can you please enable some sort of small workaround, so maybe I can do something like:

```
if (Gdx.graphics.isDesktopGL11Available()) {
  Gdx.gl11.glTexParameteri ...
}
```

data.title: Meshes does not render transparency.
Add ShaderCollectionTest
data.body: The shader tests I used (not the actual composite shader). This doesn't include all the materials/cubemaps used (and referenced in the test), only the ones I create myself. To run test you'll need to only use the debug environment and badlogic_normal or metal02 material or copy the adreno textures into the materials folder. Also note that the shaders are just test shaders.

data.title: Access to the actor when the action is completed
data.body:
_From [name.is....@gmail.com](https://code.google.com/u/108411591485795789041/) on February 08, 2011 16:41:53_

There's actually no way to get the target of the action from
OnActionCompleted, nor from the action itself (the class has setTarget, but no getter/public field).

A solution would be to change the signature OnActionCompleted.completed to : 
public void completed(Action action, Actor target)

Regards,
Carl

_Original issue: http://code.google.com/p/libgdx/issues/detail?id=130_

data.title: Angle behaves unexpected in Particle Emitter
data.body:
_From [moritzp...@gmail.com](https://code.google.com/u/110380137820502036004/) on February 07, 2011 22:18:21_

First off heads off to the particle emitter.... awesome tool.

One things which caught me was the Angle control. When setting the High value to something and having Low at 0 and than creating two points on the Life line the particles get all erratic and shake on their place instead of moving in the angle direction. The graph shows a straight line with two points. See screenshot. Only when removing the point to the right the behavior is as expected.

Shouldn't a straight line mean the same thing no matter how many points are contained?

This happens on the jnlp version published on the badlogic blog.

_Original issue: http://code.google.com/p/libgdx/issues/detail?id=125_

I find difficult to implement a behaviour because many classes (actions/hit testing/touch events) read/write values from/to Button position too freely. regards,
Cani

data.title: Support new gaming related keys in android 2.3
Box2DTest.create is missing a call to Gdx.input.setInputProcessor(this);
data.body:
_From [rolf.brocke@gmail.com](https://code.google.com/u/rolf.brocke@gmail.com/) on February 06, 2011 18:15:56_

Just thought it should be there. I tried running SimpleTest and since Box2DTest implements InputProcessor I thought I'd be all good. Inputs didn't work though and being new to libgdx it took some time to figure out what was going on.

I used MyFirstTriangle example, copied over Box2DTest and SimpleTest into the project's source path and have Triangle.java extend SimpleTest. Launching the app will show the boxes animating and colliding, but inputs won't work.

Modifying Box2DTest.create() to call Gdx.input.setInputProcessor(this); fixes this.

_Original issue: http://code.google.com/p/libgdx/issues/detail?id=122_

data.title: Fade Actions on a Group to not affect their children
JOGL and Android backend render differently
data.body:
_From [moritzp...@gmail.com](https://code.google.com/u/110380137820502036004/) on February 05, 2011 21:13:12_

The JOGL backend renders wrong when using a Stage with an Actor which is rotated and most importantly using fractions in the x and y coordinates. 

The attached screenshots shows the situation. We are seeing four actors forming a square with the same texture. Each texture is rotated to form a proper square with the borders. The actor in the lower left is not rotated and in its original orientation.

On the left image we see the false rendering with the x and y coordinates having a .5 value. The image on the right has rounded x and y coordinates so it does not show the error.

Therefore we are probably dealing with a rounding issue.

The rendering problem does not appear on the on the android backend. I can not simply reproduce it with a simple test case but the screenshots originate from the very same code once the x value is rounded and once not.

_Original issue: http://code.google.com/p/libgdx/issues/detail?id=120_

data.title: The Sequence and Parallel Action classes create objects when instantiated
data.body:
_From [moritzp...@gmail.com](https://code.google.com/u/110380137820502036004/) on February 05, 2011 18:20:34_

When a new Sequence or Parallel is created a varargs parameter is used to provide the subactions. These params are put into a newly created array every time the static $ method is called. This object creation will eventually be garbage collected which stops the program execution.

It would be better to pass an action array, which the user can control from the outside.

_Original issue: http://code.google.com/p/libgdx/issues/detail?id=118_
